name: The Dagda
shortDescription: Chief deity of the Tuatha Dé Danann, master of life and death, wielder of cosmic power over nature's cycles and abundance
longDescription:
The Dagda is the archetypal Celtic father god - powerful beyond measure, crude in manner yet wise beyond comprehension, simultaneously comical and awe-inspiring. His very name, 'The Good God,' refers not to moral goodness but to his mastery of all skills and his ability to provide for his people.

He is depicted as a figure of immense physical size and appetite, wearing a short tunic that barely covers him and dragging a massive club that requires eight men to move. Yet this crude appearance masks his profound wisdom and supernatural power over life, death, and the cosmic order itself.

As chief druid and builder for the Tuatha Dé Danann, the Dagda wields three primary treasures: the Cauldron of Plenty (Coire Ansic) which feeds all without emptying, the mighty club (Lorg Mór) whose one end kills and the other revives, and the magical harp (Uaithne) that controls emotions and the seasons themselves.

etymology.meaning: The Good God (dag = good, dia = god)
etymology.derivation: From Proto-Celtic *dago-dēwos meaning 'good god' or 'skilled god', referring to mastery of all arts rather than moral goodness

primaryLocation.name: Newgrange (Brú na Bóinne)
primaryLocation.description: Neolithic passage tomb and megalithic structure aligned with winter solstice sunrise
primaryLocation.significance: Mythological dwelling of the Dagda, later given to his son Aengus. Center of his worship and power in the Boyne Valley

associatedLocations.name: Hill of Tara
associatedLocations.significance: Seat of the High Kings of Ireland, under the Dagda's protection and sovereignty

associatedLocations.name: River Unius
associatedLocations.significance: Site of sacred union with the Morrigan at Samhain before the Second Battle of Magh Tuireadh

mythologicalDate.display: Primordial age, time of the Tuatha Dé Danann before the arrival of mortal Gaels

historicalDate.display: c. 500 BCE - 500 CE (Iron Age through early Medieval period)

firstAttestation.description: While direct textual references appear in medieval manuscripts, worship likely dates to pre-Christian Iron Age based on ritual site evidence

literaryReferences.work: Cath Maige Tuired (The Second Battle of Magh Tuireadh)
literaryReferences.author: Unknown (medieval manuscript)
literaryReferences.significance: Primary source describing the Dagda's role in defeating the Fomorians, his magical items, and his union with the Morrigan

literaryReferences.work: Lebor Gabála Érenn (The Book of Invasions)
literaryReferences.author: Multiple redactors
literaryReferences.significance: Genealogical and mythological history establishing the Dagda's place in the Tuatha Dé Danann

worshipPractices: Offerings at oak groves and earthworks
Harvest festivals honoring his role as provider
Druidic rites acknowledging him as supreme druid

festivals.name: Samhain
festivals.description: The Dagda's sacred union with the Morrigan occurred at Samhain. Offerings made to ensure land's fertility and protection through the dark half of the year

festivals.name: Lughnasadh
festivals.description: First harvest festival where the Dagda's cauldron of abundance is honored with grain offerings and first fruits

cultural.socialRole: Supreme father god, provider of abundance, protector of the people, master druid embodying wisdom and cosmic order

modernLegacy.continuingPractices: Modern Celtic reconstructionist paganism and Druidry honor the Dagda in seasonal rituals
modernLegacy.culturalImpact: Archaeological sites like Newgrange continue to draw visitors at winter solstice, maintaining connection to ancient worship patterns
modernAdaptations: Featured in contemporary fantasy literature and games
Invoked in modern neopagan and Druidic practice
Symbol of Celtic cultural identity and indigenous Irish spirituality

numerology.significance: The three treasures, the triad of powers (life, death, abundance), mastery of the threefold way

archetypes.name: The All-Father
archetypes.analysis: The Dagda embodies the All-Father archetype through supreme authority, provision of abundance, and sovereignty over life and death

archetypes.name: The Provider
archetypes.analysis: His inexhaustible cauldron and role as sustainer of his people exemplify the Provider archetype

places.name: Hill of Tara
places.relationship: seat of sovereignty under his protection

sources.title: Cath Maige Tuired (The Second Battle of Magh Tuireadh)
sources.citation: Medieval Irish manuscript preserving pre-Christian mythological narratives

sources.title: Lebor Gabála Érenn (The Book of Invasions)
sources.citation: Compilation of Irish mythological history and genealogies

sources.title: Ulster Cycle texts
sources.citation: Various medieval manuscripts containing references to the Dagda and the Tuatha Dé Danann

fullDescription: Chief deity of the Tuatha Dé Danann, master of life and death, wielder of cosmic power over nature's cycles and abundance
